Set the stage with a torsor T‾=(T,α:G×T→T)\underbar T = \left(T, \alpha: G\times T\to T \right)T​=(T,α:G×T→T) and trivialization ρ:G→T\rho: G \to Tρ:G→T. Naïvely, I'd think this would induce a division like d^:T×T→G:(u,v)↦[ρ−1(u)]−1⋅ρ−1(v)\hat d: T\times T\to G : (u,v) \mapsto \left[\rho^{-1}(u)\right]^{-1}\cdot\rho^{-1}(v)d^:T×T→G:(u,v)↦[ρ−1(u)]−1⋅ρ−1(v).

However, Remark 2.13 on nlab's torsor page suggests something completely different and I don't see what it's trying to point at.

I'm guessing that by "the canonical map", it means that p1p_1p1​ is the left projection, and as far as I can tell D=ρ∘dD = \rho\circ dD=ρ∘d which has type D:T×T→TD: T\times T\to TD:T×T→T, but that doesn't immediately match up with the statement that D(g,g)=ρD(g,g) = \rhoD(g,g)=ρ.

If, instead, we define D(g,h)D(g, h)D(g,h) to be the trivialization such that g−1h↦ρ(e)g^{-1} h\mapsto\rho(e)g−1h↦ρ(e), then it kind of works out. That said, we still need to invert one of the elements like in my d^\hat dd^, which is nowhere in the 2.13 remark.

Am I just missing something obvious here?
seems wrong to me as well... not even d(x,x)=ed(x,x) = ed(x,x)=e holds for the map there. I would encourage you to change it

Yes, p1p_1p1​ typically means the projection onto the first component of a cartesian product, and that makes sense here. But then the formula for division in Remark 2.13 looks terribly wrong. It takes an element (t,t′)∈T×T(t,t') \in T \times T(t,t′)∈T×T, uses the inverse of the trivialization ρ:G→∼T\rho : G \xrightarrow{\sim} Tρ:G∼​T to convert ttt into a group element ρ−1(t)\rho^{-1}(t)ρ−1(t), and then throws out t′t't′ altogether, leaving us with ρ−1(t)\rho^{-1}(t)ρ−1(t). This is nothing like dividing ttt by t′t't′.

Also, the definition of "trivialisation" in Definition 2.11 is misleading: we don't want just an isomorphism of sets, a trivialization of TTT should be a GGG-torsor isomorphism G→TG \to TG→T. I'm going to fix that one now.
Thank you for the sanity checks! I went ahead and munged the remark.

Here's one thing I'm not satisfied with. If we're trying to show how a trivialization ρ:G→T\rho: G \to Tρ:G→T equips TTT with a group structure, we don't need to introduce "division". We can just use the isomorphism ρ\rhoρ to transfer the group structure from GGG to TTT.

On the other hand, if we're interested in "division", we don't need to bring in a trivialization. Any GGG-torsor has a canonical division map

T×T→G T \times T \to GT×T→G

which we can define without use of a trivialization. This division map answers the question "given two elements of TTT, which group element maps the second to the first?"
So, someday I may try to work on this article some more. I am a big fan of torsors.
Hah! The action's regularity gives a canonical division map. That's way better, and now I have even less an idea what the original Remark was trying to get at.

Very nice Torsor article! Thanks for sharing. These past two night have actually had me pondering on generalizing to R-torsors and more, which you hint at right at the end. This seems like the natural structure for Energy and your other examples before you give them units.

The algebraist in me wants to start with a "ring action" R→Aut(X)R \to {\rm Aut}(X)R→Aut(X), but that requires XXX to be an abelian group to work.

Taking a more nuts 'n bolts approach, at first blush we want an action like R×R×X→XR \times R \times X \to XR×R×X→X where

r+s⋅(s′+r′⋅x)=(r+sr′)+(ss′)⋅xr + s \cdot \left(s' + r' \cdot x\right) = \left(r + sr'\right) + \left(ss'\right)\cdot xr+s⋅(s′+r′⋅x)=(r+sr′)+(ss′)⋅x

holds. This suggests a group with multiplication (r,s)(r′,s′)↦(r+sr′,ss′)(r, s)(r', s') \mapsto (r + sr', ss')(r,s)(r′,s′)↦(r+sr′,ss′). Checking associativity and invertability, it's clear this does turn G≔R+×(R×∖{0})G \coloneqq R^+ \times \left( R^\times \setminus \left\{0\right\}\right)G:=R+×(R×∖{0}) into a group as long as RRR is a division ring.

I think a slightly bigger picture clicked with me last night in bed!

The above multiplication corresponds to the group R+⋊(R×∖{0})R^+\rtimes\left(R^\times\setminus\left\{0\right\}\right)R+⋊(R×∖{0}) with action ϕ:(R×∖{0})×R+→R+:(r,s)↦sr\phi :\left(R^\times\setminus\left\{0\right\}\right)\times R^+\to R^+ : \left(r, s\right)\mapsto srϕ:(R×∖{0})×R+→R+:(r,s)↦sr, i.e. simple scalar multiplication.

But that's just a nice decomposition of affine symmetries into scaling and translation. As whole it's essentially a subgroup of ring automorphisms Aut ⁣(R){\rm Aut}\!\left(R\right)Aut(R). So the slightly wider view is that the group in our GGG-torsor is just some subgroup of symmetries of Aut ⁣(X){\rm Aut}\!\left(X\right)Aut(X) that we're interested in!

Pretty sure all this is well-known and spelled out somewhere, but I couldn't find the right keywords and had to scrounge around and learn about semi-direct products before things started to fall into place. Am I on the right track here?

I'm confused about why you're calling scaling and translation "ring automorphisms". The usual concept of ring automorphism is: a map from a ring to itself that preserves 0, 1, addition and multiplication.
Ooohh, okay. I'm actually thinking of RRR as an RRR-vector space it seems. So the Aut ⁣(R){\rm Aut}\!\left(R\right)Aut(R) we should be thinking of is GL ⁣(R){\rm GL}\!\left(R\right)GL(R)?

Translations aren't in GL(R)\text{GL}(R)GL(R).

I agree that for defining 'ring-torsors' we are interested in the group of transformations of RRR of the form

x↦ax+b x \mapsto a x + bx↦ax+b

where a,b∈Ra,b \in Ra,b∈R and aaa is invertible. This group is the semidirect product of the groups GL(R)GL(R)GL(R) (the group of transformations x↦axx \mapsto a xx↦ax with aaa invertible) and (R,+)(R, +)(R,+) (the group of transformations x↦x+bx \mapsto x + bx↦x+b, also called the additive group of RRR).

Maybe this group has some name like IGL(R)\text{IGL}(R)IGL(R), the 'inhomogeneous' version of GL(R)\text{GL}(R)GL(R). I haven't actually seen anyone call it that, but people use ISO(Rn)\text{ISO}(\mathbb{R}^n)ISO(Rn) to mean the semidirect product of the rotation group SO(Rn)\text{SO}(\mathbb{R}^n)SO(Rn) and the translation group of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn.

Anyway, whatever it's called, this group is just a subgroup of the group of all automorphisms of the underlying set of RRR. I think a 'ring-torsor' of RRR should be a IGL(R)\text{IGL}(R)IGL(R)-set (i.e. a set equipped with an action of this group) which is isomorphic to RRR as an IGL(R)\text{IGL}(R)IGL(R)-set.
